atoms: It took 300,000 years to form proper atoms

stars: Stars didn't form for about a 100 million years, but even this is tiny on the timescale of the universe

galaxies: Stars started to attract each other and clump in to the first galaxies after another 300 million years

milkyway: The Milky Way is likely older than it is placed on this timeline.

milkyway2: Astronomers are finding evidence that it potentually contains some of the first stars in the universe.

milkyway3: Seeing as it contains up to 400 billion stars there are plenty more to be researched!

sunLikeStars: Stars similar to the Sun first appeared after 3.8 billion years.

sunlikeStars2: They are distinct because they are metal-rich compared to older type stars.

sunLikeStars3: These type of stars are called 'Population 1' stars and are the 'youngest' type of stars in the universe.

sunLikeStars4: The Sun itself didn't appear for another 5.5 billion years

sunLikeStars5: This section of the timeline may seem empyty of major events but that doesn't mean nothing was happening!

moon: Theories suggest that the moon was formed when an object called Theia (similar in size to Mars) hit the Earth. The debris then collected to eventually form the Moon.

self-replicating: RNA is a molecule that can create copies of itself and is a pre-cursor to DNA. It has been found to spontaneously appear under similar conditions to early Earth.

photosynthesis: Photosynthesis is a process that uses light to generate chemical energy. A by-product of this is oxygen which wasn't available in large quantities at this time.

oxygen: Around this time the oxygen in the atmosphere massively increased, a beginning to the conditions that sustain the mmajority of life today.

eukaryotes: Most lifeforms outside of bacteria have cells with a nucleus.

eukaryotes2: From this point on in the timeline the number of key events in life exponentially increases!
